tossups.question: One member of this genus causes Buruli’s ulcer, while another causes papules to appear on the hands of fish tank owners. The kansasii species of this genus only infects immunocompromised people. Azithromycin prophylaxis against one member of this genus is indicated when the CD4 count drops below 50; that is this genus’ “avium complex.” Infection with one member of this genus is diagnosed with an interferon-gamma release assay, and causes Pott’s disease when it infects the (*) spine. That member of this genus is treated with ethambutol, rifampin, and isoniazid, and causes granulomas to appear in the lungs. That member of this genus can be tested for by injecting purified protein derivative into the skin. For 10 points, name this genus containing the causative agent of tuberculosis.

The popular folk song Ayrılıq (“AY-ruh-luhk”) commemorates the separation of these people by the Aras River. They’re not Persians, but one ruler developed the qoshma style of poetry writing in the language of these people under the pen name Khatāī. Mammad Amin Rasulzadeh founded the Müsavat Party to represent these people, who fought with an ethnic group represented by the Dashnaks during the March Days. During “Black January,” (*) Mikhail Gorbachev sent Soviet troops to thwart the independence of this people’s SSR, which fought along with its exclave of Nakhchivan against newly-independent Armenia in the Nagorno-Karabakh War. For 10 points, name these people who populate a corridor from northwest Iran through Baku.
tossups.answer: Azerbaijanis [or Azeris; or Iranian Azeris; or Soviet Azeris]

tossups.question: When one of her friends experiences a fainting spell in this novel, the protagonist doubts that it was real because “the rose tint had never faded from her friend’s face.” This novel’s protagonist declares that “a wedding is one of the most lamentable spectacles on earth” and compares one place to the grass on “a summer day in Kentucky.” This book’s background characters include the rosary-counting (*) “lady in black” and two piano-playing twins. The protagonist of this novel goes to a horse race with Alcee, a known womanizer, and is traumatized when she witnesses her friend Adele Ratignolle give birth. That protagonist of this novel feels “a certain light beginning to dawn dimly within her” after declining to swim with her husband. For 10 points, name this Kate Chopin novel in which Edna Pontellier commits suicide by drowning.

Description acceptable. In a model of this process, arenas, cues, storage, chunking, codes, and resonance are inputs. Newer behaviorist theories suggest that this process is accompanied by learning to relationally frame. Brian Macwhinney and Elizabeth Bates rejected the nativism-empiricism dichotomy in favor of viewing this as an emergent process of competition. This process generally moves through (*) receptive and expressive stages, which can be accelerated or delayed by caregivers according to interactionism. Plato's Problem asks how this process can occur with a dearth of relevant inputs to work with; Noam Chomsky accounts for that poverty of the stimulus with a theory of transformational grammar. For 10 points, name this process by which children learn to communicate.
tossups.answer: language acquisition [or first language acquisition; or second language acquisition; or language development; accept equivalents referencing learning language]
tossups.answer_formatted: language acquisition [or first language acquisition; or second language acquisition; or language development; accept equivalents referencing learning language]

tossups.question: The integral of a “white” process that follows this distribution gives a Wiener process. The convolution of two distributions gives this distribution if and only if this distribution is the inputs according to the Cochran decomposition theorem. Interpolating with a process based on this distribution is called kriging (“CRY-jing”). A low p-value in the Shapiro-Wilk tests implies the data does NOT follow this distribution. The CDF of this distribution equals one half times quantity 1 plus (*) erf (“urf”) of x minus mu over sigma times rad 2. The sum of several independent randomly distributed variables follows this distribution according to the central limit theorem. The 68-95-99.7 rule applies to this distribution, whose “standard” variety has mean zero and standard deviation 1. For 10 points, name this bell-shaped probability distribution.
tossups.answer: Gaussian distribution [or Gaussian process; or normal distribution]

tossups.question: Rulers with this title employed artists who burnished artworks with smooth agate after using transparent deer hide for masking. A vivid yellow pigment created from the urine of cows was popularized through artworks created for these rulers. In a painting, two European-style cherubs support a gigantic hourglass upon which one of these rulers sits. Another country’s nastaliq calligraphy often bordered artworks created for rulers with this title, with one painting depicting the (*) “Nine Jewels” of one of these rulers’ court. An exile in Persia led to a ruler with this title bringing the muraqqa style back to his country, which his son would later use to depict his use of war elephants. Art made for these rulers was contrasted with the western Rajput style. For 10 points, 16th and 17th century Indian miniatures often glorified rulers with what title such as Jahangir and Akbar?
tossups.answer: Mughal emperors [prompt on emperors of India; accept Mogul emperor or Shahanshāh of Hindustan or Mughal Shah; prompt on Shah or Shahanshāh or Badshah]
tossups.answer_formatted: Mughal emperors [prompt on emperors of India; accept Mogul emperor or Shahanshāh of Hindustan or Mughal Shah; prompt on Shah or Shahanshāh or Badshah]

tossups.question: This author created a character who tries to give her husband a heart attack by playing the piano while he performs a sabre dance. This author’s final play features characters such as the Murderer and the Schoolmaster and describes the Hunter’s journey through seven “stations” of life. This author of The Great Highway wrote a play in which a character lies about sleeping in a bin of oats and elderflowers, and another character claims that her pregnant (*) dog was “unfaithful” to her. In one play by this author, Agnes, the daughter of Indra, returns to heaven after experiencing human hardships. This author’s best-known play ends with the valet Jean giving the title character a razor to help her commit suicide. For 10 points, name this Swedish playwright of A Dream Play and Miss Julie.

This country’s leading flying ace and seven fellow pilots protested their relegation to unimportant assignments by resigning in the “Morotai Mutiny.” A squadron of five aging destroyers belonging to this country that participated in the Tobruk Ferry Service with the Royal Navy was termed the “Scrap Iron Flotilla” by Joseph Goebbels. Soldiers with this nationality nicknamed their frizzy-haired indigenous allies who carried injured soldiers down the (*) Kokoda track the “Fuzzy Wuzzy Angels.” Heavy fighting along that trail occurred after this country’s Lark Force lost Rabaul and fought to protect Port Moresby. The Singapore Strategy reassured this dominion’s prime minister Robert Menzies (“MING-iss”) that the British Far East fleet would protect it from Japan. For 10 points, name this country which suffered World War II attacks on Darwin and North Queensland.

One story tells how this figure was conceived when the wind lifted some sacred pudding into the air and brought it to his mother. This deity’s name may derive from his disfigured jaw, and one of his epithets is “Lord of Celibacy.” In one literary appearance, Bhima doesn’t recognize this deity and fails to lift his tail. Kesari and Anjana are the parents of this deity, but (*) Vayu is also considered to be his father due to his role in this deity’s conception. When this figure was unable to identify a healing herb, he picked up an entire plant-covered mountain and brought it to the injured Lakshmana. This figure rejected a gift and then ripped open his chest to display an image of Rama and Sita on his heart. For 10 points, name this Hindu monkey deity who does many useful things in the Ramayana.

The McCrone Report’s highly positive projections for this goal’s economic success led to the report’s suppression until a 2005 Freedom of Information Act request. John McCormick’s failure to dissuade his party from this issue led him to found the Covenant Association in 1942. After losing a vote of no confidence, James Callaghan blasted a party supporting this goal by claiming their vote against him was like “turkeys voting for Christmas.” That party won eleven seats in 1974 elections campaigning on this issue with the slogan “It’s [our] (*) oil!” Alex Salmond resigned his leadership post after the failure of a 2014 referendum on this issue, and Nicola Sturgeon requested a second referendum on this issue after “Leave” won the Brexit referendum. For 10 points, name this aim of the SNP that would withdraw a constituent unit from the United Kingdom.
tossups.answer: Scottish independence [or clear equivalents relating to the independence of Scotland; do not accept “Scottish devolution”]
tossups.answer_formatted: Scottish independence [or clear equivalents relating to the independence of Scotland; do not accept "Scottish devolution"]
acceptable: clear equivalents relating to the independence of Scotland

tossups.question: In one short story by this author, a reporter talks to a girl who is buried neck deep in a mudslide for three days. In another short story by this author, Belisa Crepusculario begins “selling words” and teaching a colonel public speaking. This author of “Two Words” created a boy who has his flute stolen by a homeless woman after his journalist grandmother neglected to pick him up from the airport. That children’s book character, Alexander Cold, transforms into a jaguar while undergoing a rite of passage of the (*) People of the Mist. “And of Clay Are We Created” is part of a short story collection by this author which is framed as the stories of a woman who falls in love with Rolf Carle. For 10 points, name this Chilean author of City of the Beasts and Eva Luna, who wrote about Esteban Trueba and the clairvoyant Clara del Valle in The House of the Spirits.

As an April Fools’ Day joke, this website created a well-received virtual assistant called “Coppy” that parodied Microsoft Word’s Clippy. In 2017, a group of Toy Story-themed role-playing users called “Woody’s Roundup” took over the deactivated accounts of neo-Nazis and pedophiles on this website. A popular browser extension for this website adds functions like timestamps; the founder of that extension, (*) Xkit, left this website after being accused of abusing other users. After Tallulah Wilson’s suicide, searches on this website related to self-harm were automatically redirected to a PSA on suicide. This website, which was the focus of a failed convention called Dashcon, was sold by Verizon for less than $3 million after its decision to ban adult content resulted in a 30% decrease in traffic. For 10 points, name this microblogging and social networking site.

In 2007, a scholar from this country promoted breastfeeding among coworkers to promote “family bonds” which would allow them to work together without scandal. A Maqsurah originally meant for the Abbas ibn Ali mosque was eventually placed in a mosque in this country thought to contain the head of the man it is named for. The term “Jahiliyyah” or “Age of ignorance” was repopularized by a religious thinker from this country, who imagined an (*) “Islamic vanguard” would protect Islam from secularism in his book Milestones. The Al-Hussein mosque is a popular site for Shi’ites in this country, home to al-Azhar University. Sayyid Qutb (“KOOT-ub”) helped to establish the Muslim Brotherhood in, for 10 points, what Middle Eastern country where he attempted to assassinate Gamel Abdel Nassar?

One character in this work lies about playing tennis and goes driving with her crush, whom she asks “why do you choose me for your charity?” That character from this novel later describes a place as “secret and silent as it had always been” and “like a jewel in the hollow of a hand.” Mrs. Van Hopper tells that woman that she will “bitterly regret” leaving Monte Carlo, and another character in this novel is tricked into shooting a woman with cancer. The sound of rockets indicating that a wrecked sailboat had been found interrupts one character in this novel convincing another to (*) jump out of a window. A character in this novel is tricked into wearing a dress previously worn by the title character by the housekeeper Mrs. Danvers, who sets the Manderley estate on fire. For 10 points, name this novel about a woman overshadowed by the titular deceased wife of Maxim de Winter by Daphne du Maurier (“MORE-ee-ay”).

In this composer’s penultimate symphony, the harp enters in the trio of the scherzo movement, playing alongside the strings and three of the horns, and the score calls for that harp part to be tripled where possible. This man cited consecutive octaves found in Mozart’s Requiem to justify consecutive octaves in the Gloria of his Mass No. 3 in F minor. After finishing his studies with Simon Sechter, this composer wrote an Ave maria for seven unaccompanied voices. Leopold Nowak (“NO-vak”) and Robert Haas edited different (*) versions of this composer’s Symphony No. 8 in C minor. This composer wrote a new scherzo depicting a hunt scene when he revised his fourth symphony in E-flat major. The rhythm of a duplet followed by a triplet, or vice versa, is sometimes called this composer’s rhythm. For 10 points, name this Austrian composer whose fourth symphony is called the “Romantic.”

One philosopher with this surname collected 16 essays that criticized the thought of people like Alfred North Whitehead and Hans Reichenbach in a volume titled Sovereign Reason. That philosopher with this surname introduced the concept of “bridge laws” and laid out a model of theory reduction in The Structure of Science. A different philosopher with this last name argued that those who do not help others are acting irrationally in The Possibility of Altruism and explored the consequences of doing philosophy from an impersonal standpoint in (*) The View From Nowhere. That philosopher with this last name opened his most famous paper with the claim that “Consciousness is what makes the mind-body problem really intractable,” in the course of arguing against reductionism. For 10 points, identify this surname shared by the philosophers Ernest and Thomas, the latter of whom wrote “What is it like to be a bat?”
tossups.answer: Nagel [or Ernest Nagel; or Thomas Nagel]

tossups.question: Arnold Sommerfeld calculated the first exact solution describing this phenomenon for the case of a semi-infinite, perfectly conducting plane. One simplified treatment of this phenomenon leads to a formula for intensity with a sinc (“SINK”) squared dependence on position for rectangular geometries. Gustav Kirchhoff assumed that the amplitude of a disturbance could be discontinuous at a boundary to derive a scalar integral equation to explain this phenomenon. An (*) imaging system that cannot resolve two light sources due to their small angular separation is said to be limited by this phenomenon. Depending on whether it occurs in the near-field or far-field, this phenomenon is described by the Fresnel (“fre-nel) and Fraunhofer regimes, respectively. A periodic array of slits creates a “grating” which causes, for 10 points, what phenomenon in which light bends around obstacles?

Ray Allen Billington analyzed the “European image” of this concept in a 1981 book that concludes it spawned the belief that the United States was a “ruthless predator.” In a 1955 paper, William Appleman Williams argued that Brooks Adams presented this concept for the whole world in The Law of Civilization and Decay. This idea pushed back against the Germanic germ theory, noting enfranchisement movements usually began in western counties. The author acknowledged that the central concept of this idea had disappeared in a seminal work published after the (*) 1890 US Census. In that work he argued that the American identity came not from “Susan Constant to Virginia, nor in the Mayflower to Plymouth” but from the American forest. For 10 points, name this thesis which attributed American democracy to a pioneering spirit of westward expansion put forth by Frederick Jackson Turner.
tossups.answer: Frontier Thesis [or frontier until “Brooks Adams”; or Turner Thesis until read; or “The Significance of the Frontier in American History”]
tossups.answer_formatted: Frontier Thesis [or frontier until “Brooks Adams; or Turner Thesis until read; or The Significance of the Frontier in American History]
acceptable: The Significance of the Frontier in American History

tossups.question: A writer with this surname published commentaries on his earlier works in the book Lyrics on Several Occasions. Two creators with this surname satirized the presidential election process in a stage show in which candidate John P. Wintergreen runs on the platform of “love.” One of those two people with this surname published the other’s Lullaby for string quartet decades after the latter died of a brain tumor at age 38. Those two people wrote the musicals (*) Of Thee I Sing and Girl Crazy, the latter of which introduced a song which is the basis for the “rhythm changes” in jazz. Two brothers with this surname wrote the songs “Embraceable You” and “I Got Rhythm.” For 10 points, give this surname of lyricist Ira and composer George, the latter of whom wrote Rhapsody in Blue.
tossups.answer: Gershwin [or Gershowitz; or George Gershwin; or Ira Gershwin; or Jacob Bruskin Gershowitz]
tossups.answer_formatted: Gershwin [or Gershowitz; or George Gershwin; or Ira Gershwin; or Jacob Bruskin Gershowitz]

tossups.question: The fungal pathogen “hairy bracket” can be utilized in a biotechnological alternative to this reaction. Performing this reaction on oleic acid produces azelaic acid and pelargonic acid for use in herbicides. Tri-ethyl-phosphine or dimethyl sulfide are commonly used for reductive workup in this reaction. The first step of this reaction forms 1,2,3-trioxolane, a cyclic precursor to an intermediate named for Rudolf (*) Criegee. Carrying out this reaction on an azo compound produces a nitrosamine, and one modification of this reaction with a hydrogen peroxide workup can form two carboxylic acids. For 10 points, name this reaction that produces carbonyl compounds by cleaving double bonds after reacting with the namesake triatomic form of oxygen.

bonuses.leadin: Two events A and B have this property if the probability of A intersect B equals the probability of A times the probability of B. For 10 points each,
parts: Name this property from probability theory. If two random variables have this property with finite second moments, then they are uncorrelated.
Given two independent events A and B, this rule, named for a British mathematician, relates the probability of A given B with the probability of B given A.

This iterative algorithm has two namesake steps, and seeks to find the greatest value of the MLE of the marginal likelihood by increasing the log-likelihood at each step. It was invented by Dempster, Laird, and Rubin.

bonuses.leadin: Tattenai attempted to halt the construction of the Second Temple by writing to a leader with this name, who allowed it based on the judgment of a predecessor. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this name of a leader identified as “the Mede,” who proclaimed that no one should worship anyone but him for thirty days.

The book of Ezra narrates how, prior to Darius the Great’s reign, these people commanded by Rehum prevented the Jews from building their temple. These people favor Mount Gerizim over Mount Moriah as a place of worship.
The Jews came under the rule of Darius and the Persians after Cyrus the Great defeated an empire centered in this city, whose reign over the Jews is dubbed “the [this city’s] Captivity.”

bonuses.leadin: This man managed his brother William’s 1965 campaign for mayor of New York City against John Lindsay on the assurance that “he couldn’t win.” For 10 points each:
answers: campaign spending [or election spending; or campaign finance; or clear equivalents to political campaigns, corporations, or PACs spending money; do not accept “campaign donations” or “campaign contributions”]
parts: Name this man who won the late Robert F. Kennedy’s New York senate seat on the Conservative Party ticket. This senator was the architect of FERPA and later served as a Reagan-appointed judge on the D.C. Circuit Court.

Buckley sued the government in Buckley v. Valeo, which struck down limits on this type of spending. In Citizens United, the Court ruled that limits on independent types of this spending violated free speech.

Buckley lost his seat to this Democrat who published a controversial report on The Negro Family while serving in the Johnson Administration and stonewalled intervention in East Timor as Gerald Ford’s UN ambassador.
answers_formatted: campaign spending [or election spending; or campaign finance; or clear equivalents to political campaigns, corporations, or PACs spending money; do not accept "campaign donations" or "campaign contributions"]
acceptable: clear equivalents to political campaigns, corporations,

bonuses.leadin: Translations of this poet’s work have focused on repeated phrases like “empty mountain” and “green moss.” For 10 points each:
answers: “The River Merchant’s Wife: A Letter” [or “Ballad of Changgan” or “Changgan Xing”]
Li Bai [or Li Po; or Li Bo]
parts: Name this Tang dynasty poet of works like “A Green Stream” and “Deer Park,” who was also the subject of a book by Eliot Weinberger and Octavio Paz.

This other Tang dynasty poem is narrated by a woman who remembers a time “while my hair was still cut straight across my forehead” and tells her traveling husband “I will come out to meet you / As far as Cho-fu-Sa.”

“The River Merchant’s Wife” was notably translated by Ezra Pound but originally written by this other Tang poet of “Quiet Night Thoughts” and “Drinking Alone by Moonlight,” a contemporary of Wang Wei.
answers_formatted: “The River Merchant’s Wife: A Letter” [or Ballad of Changgan or Changgan Xing]

bonuses.leadin: In the death scene from this stage work, an offstage women’s chorus sings a wordless minor third. For 10 points each:
answers: The Miraculous Mandarin [or A csodálotos mandarin; or Der wunderbare Mandarin]
Béla Bartók [or Béla Viktor János Bartók]
Boston [accept Boston Symphony Orchestra or Boston Pops Orchestra]
parts: Name this one-act pantomime ballet in which thieves force a girl to attract passing men by dancing ‘lockspiels’ or ‘decoy dances.’ The title character proves impossible for the thieves to kill until the girl accepts his love.
This 20th-century Hungarian composer wrote The Miraculous Mandarin and a Concerto for Orchestra. In his fourth string quartet, he instructed players to snap the strings against the fingerboard.

Bartok's Concerto for Orchestra was premiered by this city's Symphony Orchestra, whose director Sergei Koussevitzky had commissioned the piece. That orchestra hosts a summer music festival at Tanglewood, and this city's Pops Orchestra was conducted by Arthur Fiedler for many years.
answers_formatted: The Miraculous Mandarin [or A csodálotos mandarin; or Der wunderbare Mandarin]

bonuses.leadin: The British backed the liberal progresistas in this country, who had reinstated the Constitution of Cadíz, while the French backed the moderados. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country where the prospect of a Bourbon husband for the princesses Isabella and Luisa Fernanda sparked a diplomatic crisis between Britain and France.

In the Affair of the Spanish Marriages, this French foreign minister rejected Lord Palmerston’s push for a Saxe-Coburg-Gotha match. This prime minister of the July Monarchy was removed during the 1848 revolution.

The “Spanish Match” was the proposed marriage of this Stuart to Infanta Maria Anna of Spain. Protests from the House of Commons resulted in the marriage of this uncle of Prince Rupert to Henrietta Maria of France instead.

bonuses.leadin: In order to calculate this metric for an election, net wasted votes are divided by the total number of votes cast. For 10 points each:
answers: legislative districts [accept electoral or congressional or voting or political or representative or anything else reasonable in place of “legislative”]
parts: Name this objective computer-implemented metric devised by law professor Nicholas Stephanopoulos and political scientist Eric McGhee to nullify the ability to gerrymander in a partisan fashion.
Gerrymandering at the federal level "draws the borders" of these areas within the United States that define a constituency which elects a single member of the House of Representatives.

The notion of wasted votes was central to the 2018 case Gill v. Whitford in which the Supreme Court ruled wasted votes had not demonstrated sufficient harm. The Court handed down the earlier principle of one man, one vote in this 1964 case.
answers_formatted: legislative districts [accept electoral or congressional or voting or political or representative or anything else reasonable in place of “legislative]

bonuses.leadin: This man was described as “Keats + Christ + Elijah + my colonel + my father-confessor + Amenophis IV in profile” in a love letter to him. For 10 points:
parts: Name this World War I poet who wrote “O Christ, they’re coming at us!” in “Counter-Attack.”
The title for this autobiographical novel by Sassoon, originally published anonymously, came from an incident during the war where the title animal was loose in the trenches.
This lover of Sassoon was greatly influenced by him while writing poems such as “Anthem for Doomed Youth” and “Dulce et decorum est.”

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about the microbiome. For 10 points each:
answers: colon [or large intestine; prompt on gut; prompt on digestive system; prompt on gastrointestinal system; do not accept “stomach”]
parts: While microbial ecological niches exist in the mouth and lungs, the majority of the human microbiome resides in this digestive organ that contains the cecum and rectum and comes after its “small” counterpart.

Dysbiosis of the microbiome is frequently quantified using the ratio between firmicutes and the phylum containing this genus of bacteria. This genus’ fragilis species is a common cause of abdominal infection.
Both B. fragilis and E. coli are gram-negative bacteria that have this shape. Diphtheroids are gram-positive bacteria that have this shape.
answers_formatted: colon [or large intestine; prompt on gut; prompt on digestive system; prompt on gastrointestinal system; do not accept "stomach"]

bonuses.leadin: When this character goes to a confessional, the camera reveals that the ‘priest’ is actually his chess opponent. For 10 points each:
answers: Antonius Block [accept either underlined part] (From The Seventh Seal)
parts: Name this character portrayed by Max von Sydow. After returning from the crusades, this character challenges Death to a game of chess in order to prolong his life in an Ingmar Bergman film.

In this Stanley Kubrick film, astronaut Frank Poole resigns his chess game against the seemingly infallible computer HAL 9000. Later in this film, David Bowman becomes the Star Child after encountering a black monolith.

In this director’s The Chess Players, two nobles become so obsessed with the game that they ignore the impending British takeover of their territory. This protégé of Jean Renoir also directed Pather Panchali, which is the first entry in his Apu trilogy.

bonuses.leadin: The main character in this musical is told to “not come on too strong” and responds by telling his love interest to “come home with [him]” and telling her about the song he’s writing to fix the seasons. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 2019 winner of the Tony Award for Best Musical, a post-apocalyptic retelling of the Orpheus and Eurydice myth.
This god serves as the narrator of the musical, beginning the musical by repeating “on the road to hell there was a railroad line” and then introducing the gods and men who make up the cast.

Although Hadestown is the only stage musical adaptation, the myth of Orpheus and Eurydice has been adapted into many other forms, including a play called Orpheus Descending by this author of A Streetcar Named Desire.

bonuses.leadin: In 1969, Harald Szeemann (“ZEE-mun”) made his name curating the exhibit “When Attitudes Become [this word],” which featured post-Minimalist and Arte Povera art that has been described as “anti-[this word].” For 10 points each:
answers: form [or formalism; or formalist; or “When Attitudes Become Form”]
parts: Name this word. In the early 20th century, Clive Bell put forth the idea of a “significant” type that “stirs our aesthetic emotions” and developed a theory of art named for this word along with Roger Fry.

This mid-20th century American formalist art critic, who vehemently disagreed with Harold Rosenberg’s emphasis on the “act” of painting, earlier decried materialism in his essay “Avant-Garde and Kitsch.”
In his essay “American Type Painting,” Clement Greenberg championed this T-shirt-wearing, cigarette-smoking abstract expressionist, who painted “drip paintings” like Lavender Mist.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about each of the three laws of thermodynamics, for 10 points each:
answers: Noether’s theorem [accept Noether’s first theorem, do not accept or prompt on “Noether’s second theorem”]
parts: The first law of thermodynamics is one framing of the law of conservation of energy, which can be derived from this theorem that equates differentiable symmetries to conservation laws.
The third law of thermodynamics states that entropy approaches a constant as temperature approaches this temperature, equal to 0 Kelvin.

In contrast with the perfect crystals posited by the third law, this phenomenon causes a crystal to have some residual entropy at absolute zero. Spin ice exhibits this phenomenon, in which atoms “stick” in certain positions.
answers_formatted: Noether’s theorem [accept Noether’s first theorem , do not or or prompt on “Noether’s second theorem]

bonuses.leadin: This book states: “the only philosophy which can be responsibly practiced in the face of despair is the attempt to contemplate all things as they would present themselves from the standpoint of redemption.” For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this book subtitled “Reflections on a Damaged Life,” which is dedicated to the 50th birthday of its author’s most famous collaborator, and consists of 153 aphorisms. Its title is a pun on a treatise by Aristotle.
Minima Moralia was written by this Frankfurt School thinker. He is better known for teaming up with Max Horkheimer, to whom Minima Moralia is dedicated, to write Dialectic of Enlightenment.

In section 19, Adorno writes that this phenomenon “is making gestures precise and brutal, and with them men.” This phenomenon is the subject of a Heidegger essay which argues that this concept is “a way of revealing.”

bonuses.leadin: In his book Manly Health and Training, this author advised men to swim naked and adhere to a vegetarian diet while writing under the pseudonym Mose Velsor. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man who wrote the “Calamus” series of poems, which were originally published as the sequence “Live Oak with Moss.”
In this poem, Whitman describes the "varied carols" of "mechanics...blithe and strong," "the carpenter...as he measures his plank," boatmen, shoemakers, and ploughboys.
This most famous Whitman collection includes “I Sing the Body Electric” and “Song of Myself.”

bonuses.leadin: Many of these estates had their origins in the ager publicus, which was leased out through auction. For 10 points each.
answers: Cato the Elder [or Cato the Wise; or Cato the Ancient; or any clear equivalent to the senior Cato; prompt on Marcus Porcius Cato]
parts: Name these sprawling Roman farm estates. The villa rustica served as the hub of these estates, where slaves usually produced grain or olive oil for export.

This man wrote an extensive manual on farm management, De Agri Cultura, his only fully-surviving work. This man earned the epithet “the Censor” for his vigorous opposition to Hellenization while serving in that position.
De Agri Cultura extensively discusses the cultivation of this fruit. A variety of this fruit which grew on the slopes of Mount Falernus was used to make the renowned Falernian wine.
answers_formatted: Cato the Elder [or Cato the Wise; or Cato the Ancient; or any clear equivalent to the senior Cato; prompt on Marcus Porcius Cato]
acceptable: any clear equivalent to the senior Cato

bonuses.leadin: The thunder god Xevioso (Heh-VEE- Oh-So) is the twin brother of Gun in the mythology of these people. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this ethnic group where Xevioso is the son of the twin gods Mawu and Lise (“LEE-say”), the sun and moon gods respectively.
A more famous set of mythological twins are Apollo and his sister, this virginal goddess, with whom he killed the children of Niobe after the latter boasted about the amount of children she had.

In Welsh myth, Dylan ail Don is twins with this man, Gwydion’s nephew, who kills Gronw to become king of Gwynedd (“Gwin-eth”). He is analogous to an Irish god with a similar name, Cian’s son and a member of the Tuatha de Danann.

bonuses.leadin: In one work by this author, a man bites his friend on the neck while attempting to drown him in order to continue on an affair with his wife. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author, who included L'Assommoir (“LAH-sum-mwar”) and Germinal in his Les Rougon-Macquart (“lay roo-GON mah-KART”) cycle.

In this aforementioned Zola novel, the title character marries and later murders the hypochondriac Camille. The title character and her lover then marry and cope with their failing relationship in the aftermath of Camille’s murder.

Thérèse’s lover is this friend of Camille’s, who meets Thérèse while visiting her home to paint a portrait of her husband and, after the murder, is unable to paint anything that doesn’t include some resemblance to Camille.

bonuses.leadin: For a simple harmonic oscillator, this quantity is a geometric series that can be summed exactly. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity from statistical mechanics symbolized Z, which equals the sum over all states of the exponential of negative energy over kT.
The probabilistic tools of statistical mechanics were developed by this Austrian scientist, who proposed that entropy equals his namesake constant times the log of the number of microstates.

In quantum mechanics, the exponential of negative beta times the Hamiltonian, all over the partition function, gives this quantity at equilibrium instead of the classical probability. The trace of this quantity always equals 1.

bonuses.leadin: The Providence Island Company took this region’s King Oldman to England for a meeting with Charles II. For 10 points each:
answers: Miskito Coast [or Miskito Kingdom; or Mosquito Coast]
Zelaya [or José Santos Zelaya López; or José Manuel Zelaya Rosales]
parts: Name this Central American kingdom with capital at Bluefields that remained a British protectorate until 1860.
In 1860, Britain transferred suzerainty over the Miskito Coast to this country through the Treaty of Managua, though the Miskito retained their autonomy.

In 1894, a president of this surname annexed the Miskito reserve to Nicaragua proper, and was later overthrown by U.S. Marines occupying Bluefields in 1909. A Honduras president of this surname was overthrown in a 2009 coup.
answers_formatted: Zelaya [or José Santos Zelaya López; or José Manuel Zelaya Rosales]
